p: Attempts to use plant phenology to improve detection by Remote Sensing are not new ( Everitt et al., 1995; Gorsevski, 2013; Khwarahm et al., 2017) but efforts like these are often hindered by lack of easily accessible and low cost data. The impact of flowering in the spectral characteristics of plants can sometimes lead to increased confusion between classes ( He et al., 2011) which implies a need for deeper characterization ( Andrew and Ustin, 2006). While A. longifolia leaf spectral responses have been thoroughly measured ( Lehmann et al., 2015a; Gro√üe-Stoltenberg et al., 2016) there is lack of similar data collected on its flowering. Mapping A. longifolia using airborne hyperspectral sensors has been shown to be successful ( Pandey et al., 2014) but these methods are still too costly to be included in a continuous monitoring effort.
